title: Tutorial code crashes on Windows
body_html:
Problem

As reported by some Windows users, the code in the tutorial Training a classifier, which is part of the Deep Learning with PyTorch: A 60 Minute Blitz tutorial, throws a BrokenPipeError exception and crashes when executed.

Cause

The issue happens when the child process ends before the parent process finishes sending data.

Solution

The problem can be quick-fixed in two ways for the tutorial:

  1. All code is wrapped in an if __name__ == '__main__' : statement

  2. The torch.utils.data.DataLoader instances are created with the argument num_workers set to 0 (which is also that argument's default value)

Reasonable measure

This Windows problem should probably be mentioned in the tutorial. One or both of the quick-fixes could also be mentioned.
body_text:
Problem
As reported by some Windows users, the code in the tutorial Training a classifier, which is part of the Deep Learning with PyTorch: A 60 Minute Blitz tutorial, throws a BrokenPipeError exception and crashes when executed.
Cause
The issue happens when the child process ends before the parent process finishes sending data.
Solution
The problem can be quick-fixed in two ways for the tutorial:


All code is wrapped in an if __name__ == '__main__' : statement


The torch.utils.data.DataLoader instances are created with the argument num_workers set to 0 (which is also that argument's default value)


Reasonable measure
This Windows problem should probably be mentioned in the tutorial. One or both of the quick-fixes could also be mentioned.
body:
## Problem

As reported by some Windows users, the code in the tutorial [Training a classifier](https://pytorch.org/tutorials/beginner/blitz/cifar10_tutorial.html#sphx-glr-beginner-blitz-cifar10-tutorial-py), which is part of the _Deep Learning with PyTorch: A 60 Minute Blitz_ tutorial, throws a `BrokenPipeError` exception and crashes when executed.

## Cause

The issue [happens](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/notes/windows.html#multiprocessing-error-broken-pipe) when the child process ends before the parent process finishes sending data.

## Solution

The problem can be quick-fixed in two ways for the tutorial:

1. All code is wrapped in an `if __name__ == '__main__' :` statement

1. The `torch.utils.data.DataLoader` instances are created with the argument `num_workers` set to `0` (which is also that argument's default value)

## Reasonable measure

This Windows problem should probably be mentioned in the tutorial. One or both of the quick-fixes could also be mentioned.
